Analyze Knee Compartment Forces

Source: R/analyse_knee_compartment_forces.R
analyse_knee_compartment_forces.Rd

This function calculates the medial and lateral forces at the knee based on input force and moment data. It computes the forces using the provided force and moment data and applies the Moore-Penrose pseudo-inverse to solve for the forces in the medial and lateral compartments.

Usage

analyse_knee_compartment_forces(
  jr_data,
  fx_col = "walker_knee_r_on_tibia_r_in_tibia_r_fx",
  fy_col = "walker_knee_r_on_tibia_r_in_tibia_r_fy",
  fz_col = "walker_knee_r_on_tibia_r_in_tibia_r_fz",
  mx_col = "walker_knee_r_on_tibia_r_in_tibia_r_mx",
  my_col = "walker_knee_r_on_tibia_r_in_tibia_r_my",
  mz_col = "walker_knee_r_on_tibia_r_in_tibia_r_mz",
  r_med = c(0, 0, -0.02),
  r_lat = c(0, 0, 0.02),
  fmed_name = "fmed_r",
  flat_name = "flat_r",
  append = TRUE
)

Arguments

jr_data

A data frame containing joint reaction forces and moments.

fx_col

Name of the column containing the x-component of the force.

fy_col

Name of the column containing the y-component of the force.

fz_col

Name of the column containing the z-component of the force.

mx_col

Name of the column containing the x-component of the moment.

my_col

Name of the column containing the y-component of the moment.

mz_col

Name of the column containing the z-component of the moment.

r_med

A numeric vector of length 3 representing the medial vector (default is `c(0,0,-0.02)`).

r_lat

A numeric vector of length 3 representing the lateral vector (default is `c(0,0, 0.02)`).

fmed_name

The prefix for the columns naming the medial forces (default is `"fmed_r"`).

flat_name

The prefix for the columns naming the lateral forces (default is `"flat_r"`).

append

Logical value indicating whether to append the calculated forces to the input data frame (`TRUE` by default).

Value

A data frame containing the original input data along with the calculated medial and lateral forces (if `append = TRUE`), or just the calculated forces (if `append = FALSE`).
